Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story:
I was halfway through vacuuming the living room, sweat beading on my forehead, when my phone buzzed with a message from my spouse: “Don’t forget to mop the kitchen before my parents arrive!” The pressure was on—every cushion had to be fluffed, every surface spotless. I glanced at the clock, calculating how much time I had left before our relatives would walk through the door, expecting a perfect home.

Just then, from the window, I caught sight of a group of teenagers at the pool. They were laughing, daring each other, and then—one of them climbed onto the edge, ignoring the bold red “NO DIVING” sign. My heart pounded. As a lifeguard, I knew I had to intervene immediately; safety was non-negotiable. But the mop bucket waited, and so did my spouse’s expectations. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention at the exact same moment.
